text:
So just as a little insight to my work life ... today I’m working on applying for funding for our business (through grants from the government and other social institutions). This is mostly online, but includes lots of research and distilling what my company does into a crisp, clear, inspiring message to encourage funders to get on board our mission!

As well as this I’m having discussions with our partner schools about how their programme with us is going (including Villiers!). There is a lot of client management required in my role ... lots to keep on top of and clients to keep happy!
Your doing great :ok_hand:

Hey i just had a question....Kinda related to my future choices...I was wondering if after my undergraduate degree in dental hygiene can i apply for orthodontics Msc later on after working for 2years as a hygienist?
Hehe thanks
You certainly can. In fact they like to see real working experience in between an undergraduate degree and MSc
You would need to make sur eyour Undergrad degree is recognised by the General Dental Council (GDC) and UK National Academic Recognition Information Centre (NARIC)
Have you checked this? What is the Dental Hygiene degree you are applying to and at which University?
Also what A-Level grades are you expecting to hit?

Yes, I'm applying for dental hygiene and therapy mostly at Queen Marys, Cardiff, Shiefields , brimingham and i guess leeds. 
They are mostly targeting ABB
is it this one @ queen marys? <http://www.qmul.ac.uk/undergraduate/coursefinder/courses/79921.html>

text: Yes
OK great
Can I ask why you want to study Dental hygiene & therapy specifically rather than a broader Dentistry degree)?
I think it will be much harder to get into Orthodontics doing it this way around.
Well i wanted to dentistry before but than most unis need chemistry and i dont do chem..
Ohh:sweat_smile:

Because the Dental Hygiene course is a Diploma (not quite the same thing as a Degree) so I'm not actually sure that you would be able to apply for a Masters without an undergraduate degree (or doing some kind of "booster" course for a year or two)
There must be one that doesn't require Chemistry. Let's try to find one
A dentistry degree will take longer (5 years vs. the 3 years Diploma in Dental Hygiene), but your options will be much broader
not to mention your pay check will be higher :wink:
Yup....But the deadline will be a problem though...dentistry deadline is this sunday at 6
Some dental schools offer a one-year pre-dental course for those who don't have the required A-levels or equivalent (so this might be relevant for you?)
You already have the personal statement though pretty much!
plenty of time :stuck_out_tongue:
you mean the foundation dentistry courses?
Yes exactly
Yeah ive read  the requirements they mostly need non-science people
Another option might be to study a degree with a large element of biology or chemistry in it for 3 years, followed by an accelerated four-year dental course to fully qualify as a dentist
I suppose let's take a step back for a second...
What is your end goal / dream?

If orthodontics is the dream, then you should do all that you can to get on that Master's course (which probably involves getting your dentistry application in this sunday or doing a Foundation course)
If the dream is to be a hygienist, then by all means do the Diploma and get into the workplace to build up your skills.

But I think I read somewhere that your dream is to travel the world educating people on dental health & hygiene ... I can imagine being a fully qualified Dentisty would be more credible to more people vs. a Diploma in Dental Hygiene (if you were to try and start your own practice for example)
Yes i do want to travel and educate people but ill say my dream is more into orthodontics
OK cool
I'm scared right now...what do i do? i thought dental hygeine and the theraoy would get me into orthodontics

In that case, I think you should try to get on a Dentistry degree and consider the fastest way to get there without having the Chemistry A-Level (i.e. either do the Foundation year or find a course that is a bit more relaxed on needing Chemistry)
Let me have a look at a few Orthodonics MSc degrees and see what the entry requirements are
Don't be scared. It's so much better to figure this out now than after 3 years of hard work :muscle:
Hmm yesh your right
Did you drop any subjects at AS Level?
<https://www.bmh.manchester.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/courses/2018/bds-dentistry-pre-dental-entry/> <<< this is the non-chemistry route

Often if you can get your teacher in Biology to predict you an A, you will be able to apply to Queen Mary's and they will accept you even if you miss by just 1 grade
It's not guaranteed, but I know my degree asked for AAA and a few people who were predicted AAA ended up getting AAB and still got in

alright ill do that
whats the difference between a bsc and diploma?

Well it depends on the course, but a Diploma is generally more about teaching you the technical / vocational skills (i.e. something very specific such as being a dental hygienist), whereas a Degree is generally broader concepts around a general subject (e.g. dentistry)
A Degree is usually more highly regarded and leads to more professional level jobs, whereas a Diplom tends to lead to an entry-level role only

In your case, if you did the Diploma in dental hygiene, you would not be able to open your own dental practice. You would need to work with a qualified dental surgeon. Whereas if you had a degree in dentistry (and 2 years post-degree experience working as a dentist) then you would be able to open your own practice.
Think of it like this:
Once upon a time I was interested in Fashion Management.
So I explored numerous studies around that.
Instead I opted for the more general (but more highly regarded) Business Management.
If I had studied Fashion Management I would only really be able to go into the fashion industry or a very specific management role within fashion
But by studying Business I kept more doors open
I can still go in to fashion one day if I want to (I don't!)
but I also kept the door open to many other sectors and roles

So your Diploma in Dental Hygiene would qualify you as a dental hygienist (which is fantastic if that is what you want to be), but you wouldnt be able to much else within dentistry such as open your own practice.
If you did a dentistry degree, you could still do dental hygiene one day, but you keep the door open to many more routes within the dental industry
Does that make sense?
(Sorry I am talking a lot. I just want to help you!)

Oh makes sense yeah i do get it thanks.... but you know some unis do the bsc dental hygeine and some do the diploma one? so will i be able to do something better with the bsc dental hygeine degree than the diploma one?
Yes BSc would probably be better
And I think I saw some Orthodontics MScs that accept a dental degree of some kind plus 2 years work experience
but your best route to give yourself the most chance of getting on to an Orthodontics MSc would be a Dentistry BSc
as there are still some Universities that will require you have the BDS Degree in denistry
This one says as long as your degree is recognised by GDC they will accept it: <http://www.ncl.ac.uk/postgraduate/courses/degrees/orthodontics-msc/#entryrequirements>
So check if the BSc Dental Hygience is recognised by the GDC. If so, you'll be fine
Just give a few unis with Orthodontics MScs a call tomorrow and see what they say!
<https://www.gdc-uk.org/professionals/education/recent-inspections/inspections-dental-therapy>
does this mean this mean yes?
yeah ill probabily have to call them
Yes it seems fine
But of course some MSc courses will require you have a BSc in Dentistry
so you will have a smaller pool of universities to choose from to study your Masters
but it does seem possible!!
Okay than ill go with bsc dental hygeine
Again - I would call the universities to double check
and call a few to see how many accept Dental Hygiene
